iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (PEAS Promoting Equality In African Schools)
iati-activity.description:
Girls Enrolment, Access, Retention and Results (GEARR)
1) Providing low-cost, quality and sustainable secondary education. The project focuses on four key areas: enrolment, attendance, retention and results. It provides a relevant and partly vocational education to girls in schools with improved gender-appropriate facilities and practices. 2) Improving attendance by using a mobile-phone based school information management system to understand the barriers to girls access and identify girls at risk of dropping out. 3) Focusing on the safety of girls in school, including building sanitation facilities and water points at new schools to make them more girl-friendly. These are accompanied by lessons on hygiene and safety. 4) Conducting research into the issue of harassment and teasing of girls while in school. This will be new research and will improve understanding of this issue and lead to programming of more effective responses to this issue. 5) Adapting the PEAS curriculum to become more relevant to the lives of girls, and including gender sensitive health messages into in the community engagement plan; and including supplementary curriculum material to have a targeted focus on literacy and numeracy. 6) Introducing some elements of vocational training and training teachers in the implementation of gender-responsive pedagogy.

iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Mercy Corps Scotland)
iati-activity.description:
Supporting the Education of Marginalised Girls in Kailali (STEM)
1) Training marginalised girls to complete a full cycle of education. These girls provide academic and emotional support to some of the most marginalised girls, or Little Sisters, by Big Sisters, who mentor the girls through their schooling and act as positive role models. International volunteers train and support the Big Sisters, and work with them to mobilise commitment in communities and resources for the continuation of the scheme. 2) Providing nine-month "Bridge Courses" (preparatory classes and school enrolment support) to girls who have never been to school or who dropped out in Grades 1 to 3 and learning support classes to low performing girls to help keep them in school 3) Mentoring the Big Sisters through male and female adult champions from the local community facilitates negotiations with parents, adding credibility to the scheme. 4) Establishing gender-friendly school environments in schools that the projects marginalised girls attend.

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Theatre for a Change (TfaC)
iati-activity.description:
Empowering Young Female Teachers to Create Inclusive Learning Environments for Marginalised Girls
1) Identifying 350 outstanding young female teachers and training them as Agents of Change, capable of identifying and supporting girls who are at risk of dropping out, or who have left school, to improve their sexual and reproductive health, self-confidence and literacy and numeracy. 2) Posting 315 Agents of Change teachers to 225 rural and peri-urban primary schools. With the support of the Head Teachers and School Management Committees these Agents of Change will lead a range of extra-curricular activities including Girls Clubs and Radio Listening Clubs. These activities are specifically designed to support the learning and sexual and reproductive health knowledge, attitudes and skills among girls aged 11 to 15. In addition the Agent of Change teachers will work in their local communities, reaching girls who have dropped out of school, and empowering parents to be more deeply involved in their childrens education.

iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (World Vision UK)
iati-activity.description:
Improving Girls Access through Transforming Education (IGATE)
1) Increasing household economic capacity to support and prioritise girls education. 2) Mobilising target communities to actively support equal education opportunities through mothers groups, School Development Committees, local leaders and girls themselves. 3) Developing the capacity of School Development Committees to lead participatory management of schools. 4) Mobilising target communities to actively improve the learning environment for girls. 5) Supporting schools in providing an opportunity for girls personal development through the Power Within model.

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Fund)
iati-activity.description:
The Girls Education Challenge (GEC) will help up to a million of the worlds poorest girls improve their lives through education. The initiative calls on non-governmental organisations (NGOs), charities and the private sector to find better ways of getting girls in school and ensuring they receive a quality of education to transform their future.
The total budget value of Ł300 million represents the committed amount of GEC project funding for the 37 individual projects (from 01/01/2013 to 31/03/2017) forming part of the larger GEC programme. Please note that information relating to projects operating in fragile states are not displayed for security reasons.
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Viva)
iati-activity.description:
Creative Learning Centres (CLCs) for Girls aged 10-18 in Greater Kampala
1) Linking community based organisations to schools through a network approach that provides non-formal education in a wide range of subjects, in order to encourage girls to re-engage with their education. 2) Setting up 20 Creative Learning Centres to deliver education that addresses girls needs in Greater Kampala. The most marginalised girls are identified and each girl creates an individual learning action plan with the help of dedicated and trained female teachers. 3) Training teachers in this accelerated learning programme and offering mentoring throughout the programme. Voluntary classroom assistants are engaged to support these teachers (from a UK charity, making.a.difference). 4) Offering support to the families of marginalised girls enrolled in the CLCs through mentors that encourage and support girls education. 5) Linking the CLCs to enable girls to engage in an inter-school league and an annual sports competition through a mobile resource unit (with books, media and sports equipment).
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (WUSC World University Service of Canada)
iati-activity.description:
Kenya Equity in Education Project (KEEP)
1) Working with refugee communities to improve girl-friendly school environments by guaranteeing there are separate latrines for girls to ensure privacy and safety. 2) Providing girls with items they are lacking that will enable them to stay in school and improve learning, such as uniforms, stationary, solar lamps, and sanitary wear. 3) Targeting support for female learners by providing remedial academic training and secondary school scholarships. 4) Building parent and community support for girls education by adopting multi-media (SMS, films, radio) strategies to share information and generate discussion on girls education.

iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (VSO Mozambique)
iati-activity.description:
The Business of Girls Education
1. Training marginalised girls and boys on peer education, life and vocational skills. These girls will become Lead Girls, promoting self-empowerment and dialogue about home and school environments. Training teachers and School Council members on gender responsive curriculums and methods. Teaching parents about literacy and gender awareness (70 per cent are female). 2. Engaging local community radio stations and the private sector to promote gender responsive programming and messaging and to engage girls, boys, teachers, parents and communities.

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Camfed International Tanzania)
iati-activity.description:
A New Equilibrium for Girls
1) Increasing the retention and progression of vulnerable girls through secondary school. 2) Developing the capacity of female students to gain improved learning outcomes. 3) Increasing uptake and use of a mobile technology platform that supports education planning and extends learning and networking in rural areas. 4) Empowering secondary graduates to reinvest in the local education system. 5) Developing robust, engaged local capacity and collaboration in support of vulnerable childrens education. 6) Informing GEC dialogue, practice and policies in the education sector.
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Camfed Zambia)
iati-activity.description:
Child Centred Schooling: Innovation for the Improvement of Learning Outcomes for Marginalised Girls in Zambia
1) Supporting the retention and progression of vulnerable girls through primary school by providing Safety Net cash transfers, psychosocial support from trained Teacher Mentors and Zero Tolerance Child Protection initiatives (key pillars of the Camfed Model). 2) Improving learning outcomes for marginalised girls by training and supporting teachers to integrate into their teaching practices the Fundacion Escuela Nueva (FEN) child-centred pedagogy and learning resources, designed for children to lead and assess their own learning, facilitated by teachers. 3) Mobilising members of Cama  the Camfed network of educated rural young women  to monitor the projects progress, act as role models in schools and build data literacy and ownership of the project.
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Health Poverty Action)
iati-activity.description: In Nyaruguru, Rwanda, many girls are excluded from education for financial and socio-cultural reasons. Lack of education is a root cause of poverty and ill health, so HPA is working with the community to effect long-lasting change for girls in this area with funding from the DFID-Girls Education Challenge. The impact of this project will be to improve the life chances of marginalised girls, with 11,900 girls in Rwanda able to complete a full life cycle of education and demonstrate learning as a direct outcome of the project
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Link Community Development Ethiopia)
iati-activity.description:
Life Skills and Literacy for Improved Girls Learning in Rural Wolaita Zone
1) Supporting the development and implementation of Gender Action Plans at woreda, cluster and school level, based on annual Gender Audits (aligned to the Ministry of Education National Girls Education Strategy). 2) Developing local language audio-visual resources and supplementary readers for use in schools. Supporting extra-curricular clubs (Female Learners Forums, Girls Clubs and Reading Clubs); providing sanitary pads and upgrading sanitation facilities; support HIV/AIDS Circles; providing tutorial classes for girls at risk of failure or dropping out. 3) Training teachers, school directors, PTA members, Girls Education Advisory Committee (GEAC) members and School Improvement Committee members in gender mainstreaming. Training teachers in gender-friendly methodology. LCDE also provides teachers with specific training in basic reading and numeracy. School development plans are expected to include activities around strengthening basic reading skills. 4) Developing a school management simulation game to explore the challenges and benefits of girls education. Lessons from the project will be shared through study tours, girls education newsletters, zone girls education conferences and regional and federal dissemination events. 5) Building parents support for girls education by helping GEAC to carry out community awareness campaigns including the use of audio-visual resources.
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Plan International UK)
iati-activity.description:
Supporting Marginalised Girls in Sierra Leone to Complete Basic Education with Improved Learning Outcomes
1) Increasing learning outcomes for girls and building the skills needed for life. 2) Improving girl-friendly and inclusive learning environments. 3) Ensuring girls voices and needs are listened and responded to and ensuring their participation in educational decision-making. 4) Improving the access of marginalised girls, allowing them to complete nine years of basic education.

iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (IRC UK)
iati-activity.description:
Valorisation de la Scholarisation de la Fille
1)Increasing parental financial capacity to support girls in primary education. 2)Improving girls reading and maths skills through teacher training, tutoring and community reading programmes. 3) Increasing community involvement, ensuring girls access to quality education in a safe environment. 4)Increasing civil society engagement in providing alternative learning opportunities that will allow out-of-school girls to complete primary education.

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Save the Children UK)
iati-activity.description:
Promoting Advancement of Girls Education in Mozambique (PAGE-M)
1) Reducing economic barriers to girls participation in primary and lower secondary education through a programme of social transfers for education, including Education Kits and Secondary Bursaries for marginalised children. 2) Reducing socio-cultural barriers to girls education through community mobilisation campaigns and community radio programmes. 3) PAGE-M is implementing Girls Clubs in schools supporting girls development, participation and self-esteem.. 4) Training school councils in gender issues and providing funds for school improvement. 5) Improving access of marginalised girls to enhanced teaching methodologies for reading, leading to improved learning outcomes. 6) Offering additional learning opportunities to marginalised girls during crucial transition years through Transition Classes. 7) Building the capacity and commitment of government and other education stakeholders to embed PAGE-M methodologies in the education system.
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Save the Children UK)
iati-activity.description:
Pastoralist Afar Girls Education Support Projects (PAGES)
1) Strengthening the provision of quality and gender-responsive alternative basic education and formal primary education services for girls in pastoralist communities. 2) Improving physical infrastructure of schools including classrooms and access to water. 3) Improving life skills, literacy and confidence levels of marginalised girls and creating supportive community environments. 4) Improving basic service delivery, coordination and livelihood opportunities, in order to minimise demand-side barriers to quality education for girls. 5) Strengthening government capacity to sustain and scale up project outcomes through strategic partnerships.

iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Opportunity International UK)
iati-activity.description:
Innovating in Uganda to Support Educational Continuation by Marginalised Girls in relevant Primary and Secondary Education
1) Delivering a set of activities centred around savings, loans, insurance and financial education. These are delivered over two years to low (and medium) cost private schools and to households. 2) Providing school proprietor loans to schools in order to build infrastructure and improve their services. 3) Providing parents with tuition loans to support the attendance of girls at upper primary and lower secondary levels. Tuition loans are intended to address cash flow issues and carry a flat rate interest of 2.5 per cent month. Average loan size is three months, based on school terms and repaid in weekly or monthly instalments. 4) Adapting and delivering a financial education programme (Aflatoun) to girls in schools. By improving the quality of education provided by low-cost private schools, this project aims to demonstrate the potential of low-cost private schooling in providing accessible, affordable, relevant and quality education. 5) Opening child savings accounts for girls to enable families to save for school fees. EduSave is an insurance-linked savings product to protect childrens schooling against the death or permanent disability of a parent.
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (I Choose Life - Africa)
iati-activity.description:
Improved School Attendance and Learning for Vulnerable Kenyan Girls through an Integrated Intervention
1) Improving the capacity of school management committees to raise funds and form corporate partnerships. 2) Strengthening the role of families and communities to encourage girls to pursue an education in 60 communities. 3) Strengthening schools to improve the quality of education through providing training to teachers in curriculum delivery and gender; training management committees in gender policies and training teachers in data analysis. 4) Increasing resources to improve the physical infrastructure of schools to ensure girls attend, stay in school and learn. 5) Implementing Ministry of Education pro-gender policies to improve the quality of education. These include: School Management Committees, the Back-to-School Policy (for young mothers) and the Sanitary Towel Provision policy. 6) Improving the positive portrayal of women to ensure girls stay in school and learn by training secondary school students as life skills peer educators and establishing mentoring clubs. 7) Hosting large motivational mentoring events for girls and their mothers. 8) Tracking student and teacher attendance, student performance and other metrics through a biometric system which will be rolled out to all 60 intervention schools.
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Camfed International Zimbabwe)
iati-activity.description:
A New Equilibrium for Girls
1) Increasing the retention and progression of vulnerable girls through secondary school. 2) Developing the capacity of female students to gain improved learning outcomes. 3) Increasing uptake and use of a mobile technology platform that supports education planning and extends learning and networking in rural areas. 4) Empowering secondary graduates to reinvest in the local education system. 5) Developing robust, engaged local capacity and collaboration in support of vulnerable childrens education. 6) Informing GEC dialogue, practice and policies in the education sector.

iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (VSO Nepal)
iati-activity.description:
Sisters for Sisters Education in Nepal
1. Training marginalised girls to complete a full cycle of education. These girls provide academic and emotional support to some of the most marginalised girls, or Little Sisters, by Big Sisters, who mentor the girls through their schooling and act as positive role models. International volunteers train and support the Big Sisters, and work with them to mobilise commitment in communities and resources for the continuation of the scheme. 2. Providing nine-month "Bridge Courses" (preparatory classes and school enrolment support) to girls who have never been to school or who dropped out in Grades 1 to 3 and learning support classes to low performing girls to help keep them in school 3. Mentoring the Big Sisters through male and female adult champions from the local community facilitates negotiations with parents, adding credibility to the scheme. 4. Establishing gender-friendly school environments in schools that the projects marginalised girls attend.
iati-activity.participating-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (The Varkey Foundation)
iati-activity.description:
MGCubed (Making Ghana Girls Great!)
1) Introducing an interactive, distance-learning project to schools across the two districts. This is designed to respond to the scarcity of teachers in these districts. 2) Equipping two classrooms in each school with a computer, projector, satellite modem and solar panels to provide reliable power (six hours a day, five days a week). A studio in Accra will be used as an interactive, distance-learning platform, to deliver both formal in school teaching and informal after school training. 3) Addressing demand-side barriers to girls education through an additional set of activities undertaken for two hours per day after school. The activities will follow a programme of lectures, readings, group activities and discussions covering girls rights, sexual harassment, menstruation, malaria prevention, health, family planning and careers. 4) Providing residential training for government teachers, recognising the important role played by facilitators in the classrooms.

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (Leonard Cheshire Disability)
iati-activity.description:
Empowering Pioneering Inclusive Education Strategies for Disabled Girls in Kenya
1) Addressing discrimination and stigma of disabled girls education. 2) Building the awareness and capacity of service providers on the rights and potential of disabled children by training education officials, politicians, media representatives and representatives of local civil society and faith based organisations; establishing parent groups linked to each school to engage parents/carers in quarterly meetings and training on practical care; and establishing child-to-child clubs to encourage children with and without disabilities to mix. 3) Improving disabled girls access to formal education by making schools physically accessible and training teachers in inclusive strategies and Kenyan sign language. 4) Partnering with the LCD research centre at University College London to yield lessons on the barriers for disabled girls in transition from primary to secondary education.

iati-activity.reporting-org: Girls' Education Challenge - Fund Manager PwC
iati-activity.title: GIRLS' EDUCATION CHALLENGE (GEC) (ChildHope UK)
iati-activity.description:
Securing Access and Retention into Good Quality Transformative Education
1) Increasing the value attached to education by families of targeted marginalised girls (fathers and brothers especially) and their ability to develop more secure livelihoods to protect and support their daughters education. 2) Removing economic and psychosocial barriers that prevent girls being marginalised by early marriage, domestic labour, risky child migration and/or street-living from entering and remaining in primary school. 3) Supporting enrolled, marginalised girls to learn useful knowledge and skills. 4) Supporting the creation of a stimulating, safe, inclusive and child-friendly school learning environments for all girls and boys (including those with disability) in the 30 prioritised Kebeles. 5) Supporting teachers, school administrators, parent groups, community leaders, community-based organisations and child protection structures to develop the skills and mechanisms that will assure and sustain access to good quality education for the targeted marginalised girls.

iati-activity.sector: Basic life skills for youth and adults
